content.term: Stanford Type A Aortic Dissection Management
content.definition: Acute Type A dissection (involving ascending aorta regardless of origin) is a surgical emergency with mortality of 1-2% per hour untreated. Management requires emergent open surgical repair with ascending aortic replacement, often including root replacement and arch reconstruction depending on extent.

surgical_principles: Resect primary intimal tear if identified
Assess aortic root - resuspend or replace
Assess arch - hemiarch vs total arch based on tear location
Deep hypothermic circulatory arrest for arch work

operative_techniques.supracoronary_replacement: Preserve native root if sinuses not involved
operative_techniques.bentall_procedure: Composite valve-graft when root dilated or dissected
operative_techniques.valve_sparing_root: David or Yacoub if valve normal in Marfan/young patients

malperfusion_management: Coronary: often resolves with proximal repair
Visceral: may need fenestration or separate stent after central repair
Lower extremity: often resolves, may need stent/bypass

clinical_pearls: Type A dissection = surgery, always (unless prohibitive comorbidities)
β-blockers before vasodilators to prevent reflex tachycardia
Marfan patients should have valve-sparing root replacement if possible
Proximal repair often resolves distal malperfusion syndromes
Mortality doubles with each hour of delay to OR

learning_objectives: Describe urgency of Type A dissection repair
Outline surgical options based on root/arch involvement
